entry.title: Pytorch Tutorial-Training Models
entry.content:
è¿™æ˜¯æˆ‘å­¦ä¹ Pytorchæ—¶è®°å½•çš„ä¸€äº›ç¬”è®° ï¼Œå¸Œæœ›èƒ½å¯¹ä½ æœ‰æ‰€å¸®åŠ©ğŸ˜Š

Introduction

In past sections, weâ€™ve discussed and demonstrated:

  • Building models with the neural network layers and functions of the torch.nn module
  • The mechanics of automated gradient computation, which is central to gradient-based model training
  • Using TensorBoard to visualize training progress and other activities

In this section, weâ€™ll be adding some new tools to your inventory:

  • Weâ€™ll get familiar with the dataset and dataloader abstractions, and how they ease the process of feeding data to your model during a training loop
  • Weâ€™ll discuss specific loss functions and when to use them
  • Weâ€™ll look at PyTorch optimizers, which implement algorithms to adjust model weights based on the outcome of a loss function

Finally, weâ€™ll pull all of these together and see a full PyTorch training loop in action.

Dataset and DataLoader

TheÂ DatasetÂ andÂ DataLoaderÂ classes encapsulate the process of pulling your data from storage and exposing it to your training loop in batches.

TheÂ DatasetÂ is responsible for accessing and processing single instances of data.

TheÂ DataLoaderÂ pulls instances of data from theÂ DatasetÂ (either automatically or with a sampler that you define), collects them in batches, and returns them for consumption by your training loop. TheÂ DataLoaderÂ works with all kinds of datasets, regardless of the type of data they contain.

For this tutorial, weâ€™ll be using the Fashion-MNIST dataset provided by TorchVision.

As always, letâ€™s visualize the data as a sanity check:

  • make_grid æ˜¯ PyTorch ä¸­ç”¨äºå°†å¤šå¼ å›¾åƒæ‹¼æ¥æˆç½‘æ ¼çš„å·¥å…·ï¼Œå¸¸ç”¨äºå¯è§†åŒ–æ‰¹æ¬¡æ•°æ®æˆ–ç‰¹å¾å›¾

The Model

The model weâ€™ll use in this example is a variant of LeNet-5 - it should be familiar if youâ€™ve watched the previous videos in this series.

Loss Funtion

For this example, weâ€™ll be using a cross-entropy loss. For demonstration purposes, weâ€™ll create batches of dummy output and label values, run them through the loss function, and examine the result.

Optimizer

For this example, weâ€™ll be using simpleÂ stochastic gradient descentÂ with momentum.

It can be instructive to try some variations on this optimization scheme:

  • Learning rate determines theÂ sizeÂ of the steps the optimizer takes. What does a different learning rate do to the your training results, in terms of accuracy and convergence time?
  • Momentum nudges the optimizer in the direction of strongest gradient over multiple steps. What does changing this value do to your results?
  • Try some different optimization algorithms, such as averaged SGD, Adagrad, or Adam. How do your results differ?

torch.optim.SGD æ˜¯ PyTorch ä¸­å®ç° éšæœºæ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™ï¼ˆStochastic Gradient Descentï¼‰ çš„ä¼˜åŒ–å™¨ï¼Œæ”¯æŒåŸºç¡€çš„ SGD å’Œå¸¦åŠ¨é‡çš„ SGDï¼ˆMomentum SGDï¼‰ã€‚ä»¥ä¸‹æ˜¯å…¶æ ¸å¿ƒå‚æ•°ã€æ•°å­¦åŸç†å’Œä½¿ç”¨æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

1. æ ¸å¿ƒå‚æ•°

å‚æ•°åç±»å‹é»˜è®¤å€¼è¯´æ˜
paramsiterable-å¾…ä¼˜åŒ–çš„æ¨¡å‹å‚æ•°ï¼ˆé€šå¸¸ä¸º model.parameters()ï¼‰ã€‚

dampeningfloat0åŠ¨é‡é˜»å°¼ï¼ˆé€šå¸¸ä¸ momentum é…åˆä½¿ç”¨ï¼‰ã€‚

2. æ•°å­¦åŸç†

(1) æ™®é€š SGDï¼ˆæ— åŠ¨é‡ï¼‰

å‚æ•°æ›´æ–°å…¬å¼ï¼š
$$
\theta_{t+1} = \theta_t - \eta \cdot \nabla_\theta J(\theta_t)
$$

  • $\theta_t$ï¼šç¬¬ $t$ æ­¥çš„å‚æ•°ã€‚
  • $\eta$ï¼šå­¦ä¹ ç‡ï¼ˆlrï¼‰ã€‚
  • $\nabla_\theta J(\theta_t)$ï¼šæŸå¤±å‡½æ•°å¯¹å‚æ•°çš„æ¢¯åº¦ã€‚

(2) å¸¦åŠ¨é‡çš„ SGD

å¼•å…¥åŠ¨é‡é¡¹ $v_t$ï¼š
$$
\begin{align}v_{t+1} &= \mu \cdot v_t + \nabla_\theta J(\theta_t) \
\theta_{t+1} &= \theta_t - \eta \cdot v_{t+1}\end{align}
$$

  • $\mu$ï¼šåŠ¨é‡ç³»æ•°ï¼ˆmomentumï¼Œé€šå¸¸è®¾ä¸º 0.9ï¼‰ã€‚
  • åŠ¨é‡é€šè¿‡ç´¯ç§¯å†å²æ¢¯åº¦æ–¹å‘ï¼ŒåŠ é€Ÿæ”¶æ•›å¹¶æŠ‘åˆ¶éœ‡è¡ã€‚

(3) Nesterov åŠ¨é‡

åœ¨è®¡ç®—æ¢¯åº¦æ—¶å…ˆè¿›è¡Œâ€œè¯•æ¢æ€§â€æ›´æ–°ï¼š
$$
v_{t+1} = \mu \cdot v_t + \nabla_\theta J(\theta_t - \eta \mu v_t) \
\theta_{t+1} = \theta_t - \eta \cdot v_{t+1}
$$

  • ç›¸æ¯”æ™®é€šåŠ¨é‡ï¼ŒNesterov åŠ¨é‡å¯¹æ¢¯åº¦æ–¹å‘æ›´æ•æ„Ÿï¼Œæ”¶æ•›æ›´å¿«ã€‚

3. é€‚ç”¨åœºæ™¯

åœºæ™¯æ¨èé…ç½®è¯´æ˜
ç®€å•ä»»åŠ¡lr=0.01, momentum=0æ•°æ®é‡å°ã€æ¨¡å‹ç®€å•æ—¶ï¼Œæ™®é€š SGD è¶³å¤Ÿã€‚
æ·±å±‚ç½‘ç»œè®­ç»ƒlr=0.1, momentum=0.9åŠ¨é‡å¸®åŠ©åŠ é€Ÿæ”¶æ•›ï¼Œé¿å…é™·å…¥å±€éƒ¨æœ€ä¼˜ã€‚
å¯¹æŠ—è®­ç»ƒlr=0.01, momentum=0.9, nesterov=TrueNesterov åŠ¨é‡æå‡å¯¹æŠ—æ ·æœ¬ç”Ÿæˆæ•ˆæœã€‚
ç¨€ç–æ•°æ®lr=0.001, weight_decay=1e-4L2 æ­£åˆ™åŒ–é˜²æ­¢è¿‡æ‹Ÿåˆã€‚

6. ä¸å…¶ä»–ä¼˜åŒ–å™¨å¯¹æ¯”

ä¼˜åŒ–å™¨ä¼˜ç‚¹ç¼ºç‚¹
SGDç†è®ºæ”¶æ•›æ€§å¥½ï¼Œè°ƒå‚ç®€å•ã€‚éœ€æ‰‹åŠ¨è°ƒå­¦ä¹ ç‡ï¼Œå¯èƒ½æ”¶æ•›æ…¢ã€‚
Adamè‡ªé€‚åº”å­¦ä¹ ç‡ï¼Œé€‚åˆå¤§å¤šæ•°ä»»åŠ¡ã€‚å¯èƒ½åœ¨æŸäº›ä»»åŠ¡ä¸Šæ³›åŒ–æ€§å·®ã€‚
RMSpropé€‚åˆéå¹³ç¨³ç›®æ ‡ï¼ˆå¦‚ RNNï¼‰ã€‚å¯¹è¶…å‚æ•°æ•æ„Ÿã€‚

é€šè¿‡åˆç†é…ç½® torch.optim.SGDï¼Œä½ å¯ä»¥åœ¨è®­ç»ƒé€Ÿåº¦å’Œæ¨¡å‹æ€§èƒ½ä¹‹é—´å–å¾—å¹³è¡¡ã€‚å¯¹äºå¤æ‚ä»»åŠ¡ï¼Œå»ºè®®å°è¯• Adam æˆ– SGD + åŠ¨é‡ å¹¶å¯¹æ¯”æ•ˆæœã€‚

The Training Loop

Below, we have a function that performs one training epoch. It enumerates data from the DataLoader, and on each pass of the loop does the following:

  • Gets a batch of training data from the DataLoader
  • Zeros the optimizerâ€™s gradients
  • Performs an inference - that is, gets predictions from the model for an input batch
  • Calculates the loss for that set of predictions vs. the labels on the dataset
  • Calculates the backward gradients over the learning weights
  • Tells the optimizer to perform one learning step - that is, adjust the modelâ€™s learning weights based on the observed gradients for this batch, according to the optimization algorithm we chose
  • It reports on the loss for every 1000 batches.
  • Finally, it reports the average per-batch loss for the last 1000 batches, for comparison with a validation run

Per-Epoch Activity

There are a couple of things weâ€™ll want to do once per epoch:

  • Perform validation by checking our relative loss on a set of data that was not used for training, and report this
  • Save a copy of the model

Here, weâ€™ll do our reporting in TensorBoard. This will require going to the command line to start TensorBoard, and opening it in another browser tab.

To load a saved version of the model:

Once youâ€™ve loaded the model, itâ€™s ready for whatever you need it for - more training, inference, or analysis.

Note that if your model has constructor parameters that affect model structure, youâ€™ll need to provide them and configure the model identically to the state in which it was saved.

Other Resources

  • Docs on theÂ data utilities, including Dataset and DataLoader, at pytorch.org
  • AÂ note on the use of pinned memoryÂ for GPU training
  • Documentation on the datasets available inÂ TorchVision,Â TorchText, andÂ TorchAudio
  • Documentation on theÂ loss functionsÂ available in PyTorch
  • Documentation on theÂ torch.optim package, which includes optimizers and related tools, such as learning rate scheduling
  • A detailedÂ tutorial on saving and loading models
  • TheÂ Tutorials section of pytorch.orgÂ contains tutorials on a broad variety of training tasks, including classification in different domains, generative adversarial networks, reinforcement learning, and more

TensorBoard æ˜¯ TensorFlow æä¾›çš„å¯è§†åŒ–å·¥å…·ï¼Œç”¨äºå¸®åŠ©å¼€å‘è€… ç†è§£ã€è°ƒè¯•å’Œä¼˜åŒ– æ·±åº¦å­¦ä¹ æ¨¡å‹çš„è®­ç»ƒè¿‡ç¨‹ã€‚å®ƒæœ€åˆæ˜¯ä¸º TensorFlow è®¾è®¡çš„ï¼Œä½†ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡é€‚é…å™¨ï¼ˆå¦‚ PyTorch çš„ TensorBoardX æˆ–å®˜æ–¹ torch.utils.tensorboardï¼‰æ”¯æŒ PyTorch

æ–¹æ³•å¸¸ç”¨å‚æ•°ä¸»è¦ç”¨é€”é€‚ç”¨åœºæ™¯ç¤ºä¾‹
add_image()tagï¼ˆæ ‡ç­¾åï¼‰, img_tensorï¼ˆå›¾åƒå¼ é‡ï¼‰è®°å½•å•å¼ å›¾åƒæˆ–å›¾åƒç½‘æ ¼ï¼ˆå¦‚è¾“å…¥æ•°æ®ã€ç‰¹å¾å›¾ã€GANç”Ÿæˆç»“æœï¼‰- å¯è§†åŒ–è®­ç»ƒæ ·æœ¬
- æ˜¾ç¤ºå·ç§¯å±‚çš„ç‰¹å¾å›¾

- å¯¹æ¯”ä¸åŒè¶…å‚æ•°çš„æ•ˆæœ
add_graph()modelï¼ˆæ¨¡å‹ï¼‰, input_to_modelï¼ˆç¤ºä¾‹è¾“å…¥ï¼‰å¯è§†åŒ–æ¨¡å‹çš„è®¡ç®—å›¾ï¼ˆåŒ…æ‹¬ç½‘ç»œç»“æ„å’Œæ•°æ®æµï¼‰- è°ƒè¯•æ¨¡å‹ç»“æ„
- æ£€æŸ¥è¾“å…¥/è¾“å‡ºç»´åº¦æ˜¯å¦åŒ¹é…
add_embedding()matï¼ˆç‰¹å¾çŸ©é˜µï¼‰, metadataï¼ˆæ ‡ç­¾åˆ—è¡¨ï¼‰, label_imgï¼ˆå¯¹åº”å›¾åƒï¼‰å°†é«˜ç»´æ•°æ®ï¼ˆå¦‚è¯å‘é‡ã€éšç©ºé—´ï¼‰é™ç»´å¯è§†åŒ–ï¼ˆPCA/t-SNEï¼‰- è¯åµŒå…¥å¯è§†åŒ–ï¼ˆWord2Vecï¼‰
- è‡ªç¼–ç å™¨éšç©ºé—´åˆ†æ

In this notebook, weâ€™ll be training a variant of LeNet-5 against the Fashion-MNIST dataset. Fashion-MNIST is a set of image tiles depicting various garments, with ten class labels indicating the type of garment depicted.

Showing Images

  • start TensorBoard at the command line and open it in a new browser tab (usually atÂ localhost:6006), you should see the image grid under the IMAGES tab.

  • transforms.Composeå®šä¹‰äº†ä¸€ä¸ª PyTorch æ•°æ®é¢„å¤„ç†æµæ°´çº¿ï¼Œç”¨äºå°†è¾“å…¥æ•°æ®ï¼ˆå¦‚å›¾åƒï¼‰è½¬æ¢ä¸ºå¼ é‡å¹¶è¿›è¡Œæ ‡å‡†åŒ–å¤„ç†

æ­¥éª¤æ•°æ®èŒƒå›´æ•°æ®å½¢çŠ¶
åŸå§‹å›¾åƒï¼ˆPILï¼‰[0, 255]HÃ—WÃ—C (28Ã—28Ã—1)
ToTensor å[0.0, 1.0]CÃ—HÃ—W (1Ã—28Ã—28)
Normalize å[-1.0, 1.0]CÃ—HÃ—W (1Ã—28Ã—28)

Graphing Scalars to Visualize Training

TensorBoard is useful for tracking the progress and efficacy of your training. Below, weâ€™ll run a training loop, track some metrics, and save the data for TensorBoardâ€™s consumption.

Letâ€™s define a model to categorize our image tiles, and an optimizer and loss function for training:

  • Now letâ€™s train a single epoch, and evaluate the training vs. validation set losses every 1000 batches:
  • Switch to your open TensorBoard and have a look at the SCALARS tab.

Visualizing Your Model

TensorBoard can also be used to examine the data flow within your model. To do this, call theÂ add_graph()Â method with a model and sample input.

add_graph() will trace the sample input through your model
When you switch over to TensorBoard, you should see a GRAPHS tab. Double-click the â€œNETâ€ node to see the layers and data flow within your model.

Visualizing Your Dataset

The 28-by-28 image tiles weâ€™re using can be modeled as 784-dimensional vectors (28 * 28 = 784). It can be instructive to project this to a lower-dimensional representation. TheÂ add_embedding()Â method will project a set of data onto the three dimensions with highest variance, and display them as an interactive 3D chart. TheÂ add_embedding()Â method does this automatically by projecting to the three dimensions with highest variance.

Other Resources

For more information, have a look at:

  • PyTorch documentation onÂ torch.utils.tensorboard.SummaryWriterÂ onÂ PyTorch.org
  • Tensorboard tutorial content in theÂ PyTorch.org Tutorials
  • For more information about TensorBoard, see theÂ TensorBoard documentation

entry.title: Pytorch Tutorial-Building models
entry.content:
è¿™æ˜¯æˆ‘å­¦ä¹ Pytorchæ—¶è®°å½•çš„ä¸€äº›ç¬”è®° ï¼Œå¸Œæœ›èƒ½å¯¹ä½ æœ‰æ‰€å¸®åŠ©ğŸ˜Š

torch.nn.Module & torch.nn.Parameter

In this section, weâ€™ll be discussing some of the tools PyTorch makes available for building deep learning networks.

Except forÂ Parameter, the classes we discuss in this section are all subclasses ofÂ torch.nn.Module. This is the PyTorch base class meant to encapsulate(å°è£…) behaviors specific to PyTorch Models and their components.

One important behavior ofÂ torch.nn.ModuleÂ is registering parameters. If a particularÂ ModuleÂ subclass has learning weights, these weights are expressed as instances ofÂ torch.nn.Parameter. TheÂ ParameterÂ class is a subclass ofÂ torch.Tensor, with the special behavior that when they are assigned as attributes of aÂ Module, they are added to the list of that modules parameters. These parameters may be accessed through theÂ parameters()Â method on theÂ ModuleÂ class.

As a simple example, hereâ€™s a very simple model with two linear layers and an activation function. Weâ€™ll create an instance of it and ask it to report on its parameters:

  • This shows the fundamental structure of a PyTorch model: there is anÂ __init__()Â method that defines the layers and other components of a model, and aÂ forward()Â method where the computation gets done. Note that we can print the model, or any of its submodules, to learn about its structure.

Common Layer Types

Linear Layers

The most basic type of neural network layer is aÂ linearÂ orÂ fully connectedÂ layer. This is a layer where every input influences every output of the layer to a degree specified by the layerâ€™s weights. If a model hasÂ mÂ inputs andÂ nÂ outputs, the weights will be anÂ m *Â nÂ matrix. For example:

  • Parameterä¼šè‡ªåŠ¨å¼€å¯autograd
  • Linear layers are used widely in deep learning models. One of the most common places youâ€™ll see them is in classifier models

Convolutional Layers

  • ConvolutionalÂ layers are built to handle data with a high degree of spatial correlation. They are very commonly used in computer vision, where they detect close groupings of features which the compose into higher-level features. They pop up in other contexts too - for example, in NLP applications, where the a wordâ€™s immediate context (that is, the other words nearby in the sequence) can affect the meaning of a sentence.
  • å·ç§¯å±‚æ„é€ å‡½æ•°çš„ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå‚æ•°æ˜¯è¾“å…¥é€šé“çš„æ•°é‡ï¼Œç¬¬äºŒä¸ªå‚æ•°æ˜¯è¾“å‡ºç‰¹å¾çš„æ•°é‡ï¼Œç¬¬ä¸‰ä¸ªå‚æ•°æ˜¯çª—å£æˆ–kernelå†…æ ¸å¤§å°

å…³äºå·ç§¯ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œï¼ˆCNNï¼‰ä¸­ å·ç§¯å±‚ï¼ˆConvolutional Layerï¼‰ã€ReLUæ¿€æ´»å‡½æ•° å’Œ æœ€å¤§æ± åŒ–å±‚ï¼ˆMax Pooling Layerï¼‰ çš„å¤„ç†æµç¨‹åŠå…¶ä½œç”¨ã€‚ä»¥ä¸‹æ˜¯é€æ­¥è§£æï¼š

1. å·ç§¯å±‚ï¼ˆConvolutional Layerï¼‰çš„è¾“å‡º

  • è¾“å…¥å‡è®¾ï¼šå‡è®¾è¾“å…¥æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå•é€šé“ï¼ˆç°åº¦ï¼‰çš„ 32x32 å›¾åƒï¼Œç»è¿‡ç¬¬ä¸€å±‚å·ç§¯æ“ä½œï¼š
  • è¾“å‡ºå°ºå¯¸ï¼š
    å·ç§¯åè¾“å‡ºçš„å°ºå¯¸è®¡ç®—å…¬å¼ä¸ºï¼š
    $$
    ext{è¾“å‡ºå°ºå¯¸} = \left\lfloor rac{ ext{è¾“å…¥å°ºå¯¸} - ext{å·ç§¯æ ¸å°ºå¯¸} + 2 imes ext{å¡«å……}}{ ext{æ­¥é•¿}} ight floor + 1
    $$
    é»˜è®¤æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œpadding=0ï¼ˆæ— å¡«å……ï¼‰ï¼Œstride=1ï¼ˆæ­¥é•¿ä¸º1ï¼‰ï¼Œå› æ­¤ï¼š32 - 5 + 1 = 28
    • è¾“å‡ºå¼ é‡å½¢çŠ¶ï¼š[batch_size, 6, 28, 28]
      ï¼ˆ6ä¸ªé€šé“ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ªé€šé“çš„æ¿€æ´»å›¾å¤§å°ä¸º 28x28ï¼‰ã€‚

2. ReLUæ¿€æ´»å‡½æ•°çš„ä½œç”¨

  • ReLUï¼ˆRectified Linear Unitï¼‰ï¼šå®šä¹‰ä¸º $ ext{ReLU}(x) = \max(0, x)$ ã€‚
  • åŠŸèƒ½ï¼š
    1. å¼•å…¥éçº¿æ€§ï¼šä½¿æ¨¡å‹èƒ½å¤Ÿå­¦ä¹ å¤æ‚çš„éçº¿æ€§å…³ç³»ã€‚
    2. ç¨€ç–æ¿€æ´»ï¼šå°†è´Ÿå€¼ç½®é›¶ï¼Œä¿ç•™æ­£å€¼ï¼Œå¢å¼ºæ¨¡å‹çš„ç¨€ç–æ€§ã€‚
    3. ç¼“è§£æ¢¯åº¦æ¶ˆå¤±ï¼šç›¸æ¯” Sigmoid/Tanhï¼ŒReLU çš„æ¢¯åº¦åœ¨æ­£åŒºé—´æ’ä¸º1ï¼Œé¿å…æ¢¯åº¦æ¶ˆå¤±é—®é¢˜ã€‚
  • è¾“å‡ºå½¢çŠ¶ï¼šä¸è¾“å…¥ç›¸åŒï¼Œä»ä¸º [batch_size, 6, 28, 28]ã€‚

3. æœ€å¤§æ± åŒ–å±‚ï¼ˆMax Poolingï¼‰çš„ç»†èŠ‚

  • ç›®çš„ï¼šé™ä½ç©ºé—´ç»´åº¦ï¼ˆä¸‹é‡‡æ ·ï¼‰ï¼Œå‡å°‘è®¡ç®—é‡å¹¶å¢å¼ºå¹³ç§»ä¸å˜æ€§ã€‚
  • æ“ä½œè§„åˆ™ï¼š
    • å°†è¾“å…¥æ¿€æ´»å›¾åˆ’åˆ†ä¸ºä¸é‡å çš„ 2x2 åŒºåŸŸã€‚
    • å¯¹æ¯ä¸ªåŒºåŸŸå–æœ€å¤§å€¼ï¼Œä½œä¸ºè¾“å‡ºã€‚
    • æ­¥é•¿é»˜è®¤ç­‰äºæ± åŒ–çª—å£å¤§å°ï¼ˆå³ stride=2ï¼‰ï¼Œå› æ­¤è¾“å‡ºå°ºå¯¸å‡åŠã€‚
  • è®¡ç®—ç¤ºä¾‹ï¼š
    • è¾“å…¥å°ºå¯¸ï¼š[batch_size, 6, 28, 28]ã€‚
    • è¾“å‡ºå°ºå¯¸ï¼š
      $\left\lfloor rac{28 - 2}{2} ight floor + 1 = 14$
    • è¾“å‡ºå¼ é‡å½¢çŠ¶ï¼š[batch_size, 6, 14, 14]ã€‚

ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆé€‰æ‹©æœ€å¤§å€¼ï¼Ÿ

  • ä¿ç•™æœ€æ˜¾è‘—ç‰¹å¾ï¼šæœ€å¤§å€¼ä»£è¡¨è¯¥åŒºåŸŸæœ€å¼ºçƒˆçš„æ¿€æ´»å“åº”ï¼Œæœ‰åŠ©äºä¿ç•™é‡è¦ç‰¹å¾ï¼ˆå¦‚è¾¹ç¼˜ã€çº¹ç†ï¼‰ã€‚
  • æŠ‘åˆ¶å™ªå£°ï¼šå¿½ç•¥éæœ€å¤§å€¼ï¼Œé™ä½å™ªå£°å¹²æ‰°ã€‚

4. ç»´åº¦å˜åŒ–çš„ç›´è§‚ç†è§£

æ“ä½œè¾“å…¥å½¢çŠ¶è¾“å‡ºå½¢çŠ¶å…³é”®ä½œç”¨
å·ç§¯ï¼ˆConv1ï¼‰[1, 1, 32, 32][1, 6, 28, 28]æå–å±€éƒ¨ç‰¹å¾ï¼Œå¢åŠ é€šé“æ•°
ReLU[1, 6, 28, 28][1, 6, 28, 28]å¼•å…¥éçº¿æ€§ï¼Œè¿‡æ»¤è´Ÿå€¼
æœ€å¤§æ± åŒ–[1, 6, 28, 28][1, 6, 14, 14]é™ä½åˆ†è¾¨ç‡ï¼Œå¢å¼ºé²æ£’æ€§

5. ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆéœ€è¦è¿™äº›æ­¥éª¤ï¼Ÿ

  1. å·ç§¯å±‚ï¼š
    • é€šè¿‡å±€éƒ¨æ„Ÿå—é‡æå–ç©ºé—´ç‰¹å¾ï¼ˆå¦‚è¾¹ç¼˜ã€è§’ç‚¹ï¼‰ã€‚
    • ä½¿ç”¨å¤šä¸ªå·ç§¯æ ¸ï¼ˆé€šé“ï¼‰æ•æ‰ä¸åŒç‰¹å¾æ¨¡å¼ã€‚
  2. ReLUï¼š
    • è§£å†³çº¿æ€§æ¨¡å‹çš„å±€é™æ€§ï¼Œä½¿ç½‘ç»œèƒ½æ‹Ÿåˆå¤æ‚å‡½æ•°ã€‚
  3. æ± åŒ–å±‚ï¼š
    • å‡å°‘å‚æ•°æ•°é‡ï¼Œé˜²æ­¢è¿‡æ‹Ÿåˆ
    • ä½¿æ¨¡å‹å¯¹è¾“å…¥çš„å°å¹³ç§»/å½¢å˜æ›´é²æ£’ï¼ˆâ€œè¿‘ä¼¼ä¸å˜æ€§â€ï¼‰ã€‚
  • There are convolutional layers for addressing 1D, 2D, and 3D tensors. There are also many more optional arguments for a conv layer constructor, including stride length(e.g., only scanning every second or every third position) in the input, padding (so you can scan out to the edges of the input), and more. See theÂ documentationÂ for more information.

Recurrent Layers

  • Recurrent neural networksÂ (orÂ RNNs)Â are used for sequential data - anything from time-series measurements from a scientific instrument to natural language sentences to DNA nucleotides. An RNN does this by maintaining aÂ hidden stateÂ that acts as a sort of memory for what it has seen in the sequence so far.
  • The internal structure of an RNN layer - or its variants, the LSTM (long short-term memory) and GRU (gated recurrent unit) - is moderately complex and beyond the scope of this video, but weâ€™ll show you what one looks like in action with an LSTM-based part-of-speech tagger (a type of classifier that tells you if a word is a noun, verb, etc.):

  • The constructor has four arguments:

  • vocab_sizeÂ is the number of words in the input vocabulary. Each word is a one-hot vector (or unit vector) in aÂ vocab_size-dimensional space.

  • tagset_sizeÂ is the number of tags in the output set.

  • embedding_dimÂ is theÂ sizeÂ of theÂ embeddingÂ space for the vocabulary. An embedding maps a vocabulary onto a low-dimensional space, where words with similar meanings are close together in the space.

  • hidden_dimÂ is theÂ sizeÂ of the LSTMâ€™s memory.

The input will be a sentence with the words represented as indices of one-hot vectors. The embedding layer will then map these down to anÂ embedding_dim-dimensional space. The LSTM takes this sequence of embeddings and iterates over it, fielding an output vector of lengthÂ hidden_dim. The final linear layer acts as a classifier; applyingÂ log_softmax()Â to the output of the final layer converts the output into a normalized set of estimated probabilities that a given word maps to a given tag.

If youâ€™d like to see this network in action, check out theÂ Sequence Models and LSTM NetworksÂ tutorial on pytorch.org.

Transformers

TransformersÂ are multi-purpose networks that have taken over the state of the art in NLP with models like BERT. A discussion of transformer architecture is beyond the scope of this video, but PyTorch has aÂ TransformerÂ class that allows you to define the overall parameters of a transformer model - the number of attention heads, the number of encoder & decoder layers, dropout and activation functions, etc. (You can even build the BERT model from this single class, with the right parameters!) TheÂ torch.nn.TransformerÂ class also has classes to encapsulate the individual components (TransformerEncoder,Â TransformerDecoder) and subcomponents (TransformerEncoderLayer,Â TransformerDecoderLayer). For details, check out theÂ documentationÂ on transformer classes, and the relevantÂ tutorialÂ on pytorch.org.

Other Layers and Functions

Data Manipulation Layers

There are other layer types that perform important functions in models, but donâ€™t participate in the learning process themselves.

Max pooling

Max poolingÂ (and its twin, min pooling) reduce a tensor by combining cells, and assigning the maximum value of the input cells to the output cell. (We saw this ) For example:

If you look closely at the values above, youâ€™ll see that each of the values in the maxpooled output is the maximum value of each quadrant of the 6x6 input.

Normalization layers

Normalization layersÂ re-center and normalize the output of one layer before feeding it to another. Centering and scaling the intermediate tensors has a number of beneficial effects, such as letting you use higher learning rates without exploding/vanishing gradients.

Running the cell above, weâ€™ve added a large scaling factor and offset to an input tensor; you should see the input tensorâ€™sÂ mean()Â somewhere in the neighborhood of 15. After running it through the normalization layer, you can see that the values are smaller, and grouped around zero - in fact, the mean should be very small (> 1e-8).

This is beneficial because many activation functions (discussed below) have their strongest gradients near 0, but sometimes suffer from vanishing or exploding gradients for inputs that drive them far away from zero. Keeping the data centered around the area of steepest gradient will tend to mean faster, better learning and higher feasible learning rates.

Dropout layers

Dropout layersÂ are a tool for encouragingÂ sparse representations ç¨€ç–è¡¨ç¤ºÂ in your model - that is, pushing it to do inference with less data.

Dropout layers work by randomly setting parts of the input tensorÂ zero during trainingÂ - dropout layers are always turned off for inference æ¨ç†. This forces the model to learn against this masked or reduced dataset. For example:

Above, you can see the effect of dropout on a sample tensor. You can use the optionalÂ pÂ argument to set the probability of an individual weight dropping out; if you donâ€™t it defaults to 0.5.

Activation Functions

Activation functions make deep learning possible. A neural network is really a program - with many parameters - thatÂ simulatesÂ a mathematical function. If all we did was multiple tensors by layer weights repeatedly, we could onlyÂ simulateÂ linear functions;Â further, there would be no point to having many layers, as the whole network could be reduced to a single matrix multiplication. InsertingÂ non-linearÂ activation functions between layers is what allows a deep learning model toÂ simulateÂ any function, rather than just linear ones.

torch.nn.ModuleÂ has objects encapsulating å°è£… all of the major activation functions including ReLU and its many variants, Tanh, Hardtanh, sigmoid, and more. It also includes other functions, such as Softmax, that are most useful at the output stage of a model.

Loss Functions

Loss functions tell us how far a modelâ€™s prediction is from the correct answer. PyTorch contains a variety of loss functions, including common MSE (mean squared error = L2 norm), Cross Entropy Loss and Negative Likelihood Loss (useful for classifiers), and others.

Advanced: Replacing Layers

  • waiting to be updatedğŸ˜€

entry.title: Pytorch Tutorial-Autograd
entry.content:
è¿™æ˜¯æˆ‘å­¦ä¹ Pytorchæ—¶è®°å½•çš„ä¸€äº›ç¬”è®° ï¼Œå¸Œæœ›èƒ½å¯¹ä½ æœ‰æ‰€å¸®åŠ©ğŸ˜Š

Autograd

autograd çš„ç”¨æ­¦ä¹‹åœ°ï¼šå®ƒè·Ÿè¸ªæ¯æ¬¡è®¡ç®—çš„å†å²è®°å½•ã€‚PyTorch æ¨¡å‹ä¸­çš„æ¯ä¸ªè®¡ç®—å¼ é‡éƒ½å¸¦æœ‰å…¶è¾“å…¥å¼ é‡å’Œç”¨äºåˆ›å»ºå¼ é‡çš„å‡½æ•°çš„å†å²è®°å½•ã€‚ç»“åˆç”¨äºä½œç”¨äºå¼ é‡çš„ PyTorch å‡½æ•°ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ªå‡½æ•°éƒ½æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªç”¨äºè®¡ç®—è‡ªå·±çš„å¯¼æ•°çš„å†…ç½®å®ç°ï¼Œè¿™å¤§å¤§åŠ å¿«äº†å­¦ä¹ æ‰€éœ€çš„å±€éƒ¨å¯¼æ•°çš„è®¡ç®—é€Ÿåº¦ã€‚

ä¸¾ä¾‹

Be aware than onlyÂ leaf nodesÂ of the computation have their gradients computed. If you tried, for example,Â print(c.grad)Â youâ€™d get backÂ None. In this simple example, only the input is a leaf node, so only it has gradients computed.

Jacobian

If you have a function with anÂ n-dimensional input and m-dimensional output,Â , the complete gradient is a matrix of the derivative of every output with respect to every input, called theÂ Jacobian:
$$
\begin{align}J=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\frac{\partial y_{1}}{\partial x_{1}} & \cdots & \frac{\partial y_{1}}{\partial x_{n}}\
\vdots & \ddots & \vdots\
\frac{\partial y_{m}}{\partial x_{1}} & \cdots & \frac{\partial y_{m}}{\partial x_{n}}
\end{array}\right)\end{align}
$$
If you have a second function, $l=g\left(\vec{y}\right)$ that takes m-dimensional input (that is, the same dimensionality as the output above), and returns a scalar output, you can express its gradients with respect to $\vec{y}$ as a column vector, $v=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}\frac{\partial l}{\partial y_{1}} & \cdots & \frac{\partial l}{\partial y_{m}}\end{array}\right)^{T}$ - which is really just a one-column Jacobian.

More concretely, imagine the first function as your PyTorch model (with potentially many inputs and many outputs) and the second function as a loss function (with the modelâ€™s output as input, and the loss value as the scalar output).

If we multiply the first functionâ€™s Jacobian by the gradient of the second function, and apply the chain rule, we get:

$$
\begin{align}J^{T}\cdot v=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\frac{\partial y_{1}}{\partial x_{1}} & \cdots & \frac{\partial y_{m}}{\partial x_{1}}\
\vdots & \ddots & \vdots\
\frac{\partial y_{1}}{\partial x_{n}} & \cdots & \frac{\partial y_{m}}{\partial x_{n}}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\frac{\partial l}{\partial y_{1}}\
\vdots\
\frac{\partial l}{\partial y_{m}}
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\frac{\partial l}{\partial x_{1}}\
\vdots\
\frac{\partial l}{\partial x_{n}}
\end{array}\right)\end{align}
$$

Note: You could also use the equivalent operation $v^{T}\cdot J$, and get back a row vector.

The resulting column vector is the gradient of the second function with respect to the inputs of the first - or in the case of our model and loss function, the gradient of the loss with respect to the model inputs.

torch.autograd is an engine for computing these products. This is how we accumulate the gradients over the learning weights during the backward pass.

For this reason, the backward() call can also take an optional vector input. This vector represents a set of gradients over the tensor, which are multiplied by the Jacobian of the autograd-traced tensor that precedes it. Letâ€™s try a specific example with a small vector:

å—¯ï¼Œè¿™ä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯åé¢çš„ç¤ºä¾‹2æ‰€æ¼”ç¤ºçš„ï¼Œæˆ³æˆ‘ç›´è¾¾

High-Level API

There is an API on autograd that gives you direct access to important differential matrix and vector operations. In particular, it allows you to calculate the Jacobian and theÂ HessianÂ matrices of a particular function for particular inputs. (The Hessian is like the Jacobian, but expresses all partialÂ secondÂ derivatives.) It also provides methods for taking vector products with these matrices.

  • è¿˜æœ‰èƒ½å¤Ÿç›´æ¥è®¡ç®—å‘é‡-é›…å„æ¯”ä¹˜ç§¯çš„functionï¼šTheÂ torch.autograd.functional.jvp()Â method performs the same matrix multiplication asÂ vjp()Â with the operands reversed
  • å…¨æ–‡é‡ç‚¹æ„Ÿè§‰ä¸å¤Ÿçªå‡ºï¼Œæˆ‘è®©AIç»™äº†ä¸€ä»½ç¬”è®°

AIæ€»ç»“

PyTorch Autograd åŠŸèƒ½æ€»ç»“

PyTorch çš„ autogradï¼ˆè‡ªåŠ¨å¾®åˆ†ï¼‰æ˜¯å…¶æ ¸å¿ƒåŠŸèƒ½ä¹‹ä¸€ï¼Œç”¨äº è‡ªåŠ¨è®¡ç®—å¼ é‡çš„æ¢¯åº¦ï¼Œæ”¯æŒåŠ¨æ€è®¡ç®—å›¾ï¼ˆDynamic Computation Graphï¼‰ï¼Œæ˜¯è®­ç»ƒç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œçš„åŸºç¡€ã€‚ä»¥ä¸‹æ˜¯å…³é”®ç‚¹æ€»ç»“å’Œç¤ºä¾‹ï¼š

entry.title: Pytorch Tutorial-Tensors
entry.content:
è¿™æ˜¯æˆ‘å­¦ä¹ Pytorchæ—¶è®°å½•çš„ä¸€äº›ç¬”è®° ï¼Œå¸Œæœ›èƒ½å¯¹ä½ æœ‰æ‰€å¸®åŠ©ğŸ˜Š

  • You will sometimes see aÂ 1-dimensional tensor called aÂ vector.
  • Likewise, a 2-dimensional tensor is often referred to as aÂ matrix.
  • Anything with more than two dimensions is generally just called a tensor

Creating Tensors

  • using factory methods

Random Tensors and Seeding

  • å¯ä»¥å‘ç°random1,2 ä¸ 3,4å®Œå…¨ä¸€è‡´ï¼Œéšæœºæ•°ç”Ÿæˆå™¨çš„ç§å­éƒ½æ˜¯1729ï¼Œè¿™æ ·å¯ä»¥ä¿è¯â€œç»“æœå¯å¤ç°â€
  • r1ä¸r2çš„å€¼ä¸åŒï¼Œå› ä¸ºç”Ÿæˆr1åéšæœºæ•°ç”Ÿæˆå™¨çš„çŠ¶æ€æ›´æ–°äº†ï¼Œè€Œr3ç›¸å½“äºé‡ç½®äº†ï¼Œç±»ä¼¼äºexecve

Tensor Shapes

  • Â when youâ€™re performing operations on two or more tensors, they will need to be of the sameÂ shapeÂ - that is, having the same number of dimensions and the same number of cells in each dimension. For that, we have theÂ torch.*_like()Â methods:
  • Below that, we call theÂ .empty_like(),Â .zeros_like(),Â  andÂ .rand_like()Â methods. Using theÂ .shapeÂ property, we can verify that each of these methods returns a tensor of identical dimensionality and extent.
  • UsingÂ torch.tensor()Â is the most straightforward way to create a tensor if you already have data in a Python tuple or list. As shown above, nesting the collections will result in a multi-dimensional tensor.(åµŒå¥—é›†åˆå°†äº§ç”Ÿå¤šç»´å¼ é‡)
    Note:Â torch.tensor()Â creates a copy of the data.

Tensor Data Types

é»˜è®¤æ˜¯float32, Available data types include:

  • torch.bool
  • torch.int8
  • torch.uint8
  • torch.int16
  • torch.int32
  • torch.int64
  • torch.half
  • torch.float
  • torch.double
  • torch.bfloat

è®¾ç½®æ•°æ®ç±»å‹æœ‰ä¸¤ç§æ–¹å¼ï¼Œä¸€æ˜¯åœ¨åˆ›å»ºæ—¶è®¾ç½®ï¼ŒäºŒæ˜¯ä½¿ç”¨.to()å‡½æ•°

Math & Logic with Tensors

  • å¤§éƒ¨åˆ†è¿ç®—éƒ½å’Œä½ çš„ç›´è§‰å·®ä¸å¤šï¼Œè€Œä¸”æ¯”è¾ƒâ€œèªæ˜â€

In Brief: Tensor Broadcasting

The rules for broadcasting are:

  • Each tensor must have at least one dimension - no empty tensors.
  • Comparing the dimensionÂ sizesÂ of the two tensors,Â going from last to first ä»åå¾€å‰:
    • Each dimension must be equal,Â or
    • One of the dimensions must be ofÂ sizeÂ 1,Â or
    • The dimension does not exist in one of the tensors
  • some correct examples:For more information on broadcasting, see theÂ PyTorch documentationÂ on the topic.

More Math with Tensors

This is a small sample of For more details and the full inventory of math functions, have a look at theÂ documentation.
ç»™å‡ºä¸€äº›ç»å…¸ç¤ºä¾‹ï¼š

Copying Tensors

  • clone()
  • There is an important thing to be aware of when usingÂ clone().Â If your source tensor has autograd, enabled then so will the clone.Â 
  • TheÂ detach()Â methodÂ detaches the tensor from its computation history.Â It says, â€œdo whatever comes next as if autograd was off.â€ It does thisÂ withoutÂ changingÂ aÂ - you can see that when we printÂ aÂ again at the end, it retains itsÂ requires_grad=TrueÂ property.

Moving to GPU

å¼•å…¥ï¼šOne of the major advantages of PyTorch is its robust acceleration on CUDA-compatible Nvidia GPUs. (â€œCUDAâ€ stands forÂ Compute Unified Device Architecture, which is Nvidiaâ€™s platform for parallel computing.) So far, everything weâ€™ve done has been on CPU. How do we move to the faster hardware?

CPUåœ¨RAMä¸­è¿›è¡Œè®¡ç®—ï¼Œè€ŒGPUæä¾›äº†é™„åŠ å†…å­˜ï¼Œç”¨GPUè®¡ç®—æ—¶éœ€è¦å°†æ•°æ®è¿ç§»åˆ°GPU

åˆ›å»ºæ—¶è¿ç§»

  • å¼ é‡é»˜è®¤åˆ›å»ºåœ¨CPUä¸Šï¼Œä½ å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨deviceæ¥åˆ¶å®šè®¾å¤‡

  • ä¸€ä¸ªå¥½çš„ä¹ æƒ¯æ˜¯ä½¿ç”¨my_deviceæ¥è¡¨å¾è‡ªå·±çš„è®¾å¤‡ï¼Œè€Œä¸ç›´æ¥ä½¿ç”¨å­—ç¬¦ä¸²

to()è¿ç§»

It is important to know that in order to do computation involving two or more tensors,Â all of the tensors must be on the same device.

Manipulating Tensor Shapes

PyTorch models generally expectÂ batchesÂ of input.For example, imagine having a model that works on 3 x 226 x 226 images - a 226-pixel square with 3 color channels. When you load and transform it, youâ€™ll get a tensor of shapeÂ (3, 226, 226). Your model, though, is expecting input of shapeÂ (N, 3, 226, 226), whereÂ NÂ is the number of images in the batch. So how do you make a batch of one?

  • TheÂ unsqueeze()Â method adds a dimension of extentÂ 1.Â unsqueeze(0)Â adds it as a new zeroth dimension - now you have a batch of one!
  • å…¶å®å¢åŠ æˆ–å‡å°‘ä¸€ä¸ªèŒƒå›´ä¸º1çš„ç»´åº¦ï¼Œå…¶å®å¯¹æ•°æ®æœ¬èº«å¹¶æ²¡æœ‰å½±å“ï¼Œè¿™ä¹Ÿèƒ½æç¤ºæˆ‘ä»¬ï¼šÂ Calls toÂ squeeze()Â andÂ unsqueeze()Â can only act on dimensions of extentÂ 1Â because to do otherwise would change the number of elements in the tensor.

Sometimes youâ€™ll want to change the shape of a tensor more radically, while still preserving the number of elements and their contents. One case where this happens is at the interface between a convolutional layer of a model and a linear layer of the model - this is common in image classification models. A convolution kernel will yield an output tensor of shapeÂ features x width x height,Â but the following linear layer expects aÂ 1-dimensional input.Â reshape()Â will do this for you, provided that the dimensions you request yield the same number of elements as the input tensor has:

NumPy Bridge
